focus_skills: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
Inference from sample statistics and margin of error

questions.question: The line passes through the points (1, 3) and (4, 9). What is the slope of the line?
questions.explanation: The slope m is given by <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>9</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>, which simplifies to <math><mfrac><mn>6</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember to use the slope formula correctly by subtracting y-coordinates over x-coordinates from two points on the line.

questions.question: The equation of a line is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. What does the number -8 represent?
questions.explanation: In the slope-intercept form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, b is the y-intercept, so -8 is the y-intercept.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the components of the slope-intercept form to understand what each number in the equation represents.

questions.question: Solve for t in the equation <math><mn>4</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>28</mn></math>.
questions.explanation: Subtract 12 from both sides: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Divide by 4: <math><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Enter as an integer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations step by step.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A recipe requires 3 cups of flour for every 2 cups of sugar. If 6 cups of flour are used, how many cups of sugar are needed?
questions.explanation: The ratio is 3:2. For 6 cups flour, which is twice 3, sugar is twice 2, so 4 cups.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Set up proportions to solve ratio problems by cross-multiplying.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: Solve the system: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> and <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. What is the value of x?
questions.explanation: Multiply the second equation by 2: <math><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. Add to the first: <math><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use elimination or substitution methods for systems of equations, checking by plugging back in.

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Distribute: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math> = <math><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Distribute constants carefully and combine like terms to simplify expressions.

questions.question: Solve the inequality <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>></mo><mn>7</mn></math> for x. What is the smallest integer value of x that satisfies the inequality?
questions.explanation: Add 5: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Divide by 3: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Smallest integer is 5. Enter as integer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving inequalities, remember to flip the sign if multiplying or dividing by a negative number.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='250' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='150' y1='20' x2='150' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='150,90 160,90 160,100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><text x='160' y='90' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>90°</text><text x='80' y='90' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>(2x + 10)°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two lines intersecting perpendicularly. The top-right quadrant is marked with a square symbol indicating 90 degrees. The adjacent top-left angle is labeled with the expression (2x + 10) degrees.
questions.question: In the figure above, two lines intersect to form a right angle. If the measure of the adjacent angle is represented by <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
When two lines are perpendicular, they form four right angles. Therefore, the angle adjacent to the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math> angle must also measure <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. 

Set up the equation: 
<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn></math>

Subtract 10 from both sides:
<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn></math>

Divide by 2:
<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math>
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='250' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='150' y1='20' x2='150' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='150,90 160,90 160,100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><text x='160' y='90' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>90°</text><text x='80' y='90' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' fill='red'>2(40)+10 = 90°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The intersecting lines with the variable x replaced by 40, showing that the equation evaluates to 90 degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that if two lines are perpendicular, all four angles formed at the intersection are <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Set the given algebraic expression equal to 90 to solve for the variable.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The scores are 80, 85, 90, 95, 100. What is the median score?
questions.explanation: The middle value in the ordered list is 90.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For median, order the data and find the middle value; for even number, average the two middle.

questions.question: The line has equation <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. What is the y-intercept?
questions.explanation: Rewrite as <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, so y-intercept is -2.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Convert to slope-intercept form to easily identify intercepts.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='0' y1='150' x2='400' y2='150' stroke='#333' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='0' x2='200' y2='300' stroke='#333' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='120' y1='50' x2='360' y2='230' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='120' cy='50' r='4' fill='red'/><circle cx='360' cy='230' r='4' fill='red'/><text x='70' y='45' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>(-4, 5)</text><text x='330' y='250' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>(8, -4)</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A line in the xy-plane passing through the points (-4, 5) and (8, -4).
questions.question: The graph of a linear equation is shown in the xy-plane above. Which of the following equations represents this line?
questions.explanation:
1. Find the slope (m): <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
2. Use point-slope form with (-4, 5): <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
3. Simplify to Slope-Intercept: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>→</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
4. Convert to Standard Form (Ax + By = C): Multiply by 4: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. Add 3x to both sides: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='0' y1='150' x2='400' y2='150' stroke='#333' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='0' x2='200' y2='300' stroke='#333' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='120' y1='50' x2='360' y2='230' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='120,50 360,50 360,230' fill='none' stroke='blue' stroke-dasharray='4'/><text x='240' y='40' fill='blue' font-size='12'>Run = 12</text><text x='365' y='140' fill='blue' font-size='12'>Rise = -9</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: A slope triangle showing a rise of -9 and a run of 12, resulting in a slope of -3/4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a question provides Standard Form options (Ax + By = C), remember that the slope is -A/B. Here, A=3 and B=4, so the slope is -3/4. This allows you to quickly check the options against your calculated slope.

questions.question: Solve <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. What is the sum of the solutions?
questions.explanation: Factors to <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, solutions 2 and 4, sum 6. Enter as integer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For quadratics, use factoring or quadratic formula; sum of roots is -b/a.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: The system <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> and <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></math> has infinitely many solutions. What is k?
questions.explanation: Second equation is twice the first, so k=10 for dependent system.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For infinite solutions, equations must be multiples of each other.

questions.question: A price increases by 20% then decreases by 20%. What is the net percentage change?
questions.score_improvement_tip: Calculate successive percentages on updated values, not original.

questions.question: In a right triangle with legs 5 and 12, what is the hypotenuse? Enter as decimal to nearest tenth.
questions.explanation: Hypotenuse = <math><msqrt><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>169</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Apply Pythagorean theorem for right triangles.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='0' y1='200' x2='400' y2='200' stroke='#333' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='50' y1='0' x2='50' y2='300' stroke='#333' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M 55 120 Q 180 340 300 100' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='50' cy='110' r='4' fill='red'/><text x='60' y='115' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>(0, 3)</text><circle cx='110' cy='200' r='4' fill='red'/><text x='100' y='190' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>(2, 0)</text><circle cx='230' cy='200' r='4' fill='red'/><text x='220' y='190' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>(6, 0)</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A parabola opening upwards in the xy-plane. It intersects the x-axis at (2, 0) and (6, 0), and crosses the y-axis at (0, 3).
questions.question: The graph of the quadratic function <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is shown in the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane above. Which of the following equations defines <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
1. Identify the x-intercepts: The graph crosses the x-axis at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. In factored form, these roots correspond to the factors <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. This eliminates option B.
2. Use the y-intercept: The graph passes through <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Substitute these coordinates into the general factored form <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
3. Solve for <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi></math>: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>⇒</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>⇒</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
4. The final equation is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='0' y1='200' x2='400' y2='200' stroke='#333' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='50' y1='0' x2='50' y2='300' stroke='#333' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M 55 120 Q 180 340 300 100' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2'/><text x='150' y='250' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='14' fill='blue' font-weight='bold'>f(x) = a(x - r₁)(x - r₂)</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The graph of the parabola with the generic factored form formula highlighted, emphasizing that r1 and r2 are the x-intercepts.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When given x-intercepts, start with the factored form <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></math>. Don't assume <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>; always verify by plugging in a point like the y-intercept.

questions.question: A car travels at 50 mph for t hours, then 60 mph for 2 hours, total distance 220 miles. What is t?
questions.explanation: <math><mn>50</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>220</mn></math>, <math><mn>50</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></math>, t=2.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Set up equations for word problems by defining variables clearly.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A sample mean is 50 with margin of error 4. What is the upper bound of the confidence interval? Enter as integer.
questions.explanation: Upper bound = mean + margin = 50 + 4 = 54.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Add and subtract margin of error from the mean for confidence intervals.

questions.question: A circle has equation <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. What is the radius?
questions.explanation: Standard form, radius is sqrt(16)=4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall the standard equation of a circle to identify center and radius.

questions.question: In a right triangle, sin(theta)=3/5. What is cos(theta)?
questions.explanation: Opposite 3, hypotenuse 5, adjacent 4, cos=adjacent/hyp=4/5.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use Pythagorean triples to find missing sides in trig problems.
